Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Evaluating the Psychometric Properties of a Measure of Mathematical Mindset Attitudes Across Cultures
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research is focused on evaluating the Dweck Mindset Instrument. Mindset involves how one views the idea of intelligence, namely whether one views intelligence as something that can grow or if one views intelligence as something more unchanging. Mindset has been linked to academic achievement and while much of the research involving mindset and achievement is very promising the most popular measurement tool for mindset, the Dweck Mindset Instrument, is lacking in some areas in showing that it is a valid and reliable instrument to use. One area in particular is if this measurement can work across cultures. This project will work on collecting and evaluating data from the Dweck Mindset Instrument and related constructs in both American and Japanese students in order to better evaluate if this measure is valid. The researcher will be working with Dr. Ayumi Tanaka who has been studying mindset theories at Doshisha University.

One specific psychometric evaluation will determine if the scale has measurement invariance, which gives support to it measuring the same construct in both cultures. If the scale is not measurement invariant it cannot be used to compared scores across cultures. Additionally many researchers using this scale have been modifying the scale, using only one subscale, and even scoring the measure differently. This project will determine if these different ways to interpret the scale will have a sizeable impact on the results of the statistical tests used. Since some researchers have been modifying the Dweck Mindset Instrument to focus on certain attitudes, this project will evaluate if that modifications can be valid using a mathematically focused mindset scale. Additionally, a focus on mathematical issues is of interest due to both a mediocre math performance in United States students as compared to other countries and an increase in need for STEM educated citizens.

This award, under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program, supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science (JSPS).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to evaluate how the Dweck Mindset Instrument functions across cultures, specifically American and Japanese cultures. The Dweck Mindset Instrument seeks to measures one’s views of intelligence, that is, is intelligence something static or something that can grow. Someone with an incremental mindset views intelligence as something that can be improved upon while those with an entity mindset views intelligence as stable and believes there is not much you can do to change it. There has been an abundance of research comparing Eastern and Western learning attitudes. This cross-cultural learning attitude research has often found that Eastern cultures put more emphasis on study and effort while Western cultures view innate intelligence as a bigger component of academic achievement.

However, these cross cultural studies used a variety of methods to gain this information and the Dweck Mindset Instrument could prove to be a useful standardized measure to evaluate similar psychology constructs. This project was largely focused on if the Dweck Mindset Instrument was invariant across these two cultures. It is simply not enough to translate an instrument and assume it is working in a similar fashion. If a measure is measurement invariant it means that the outcomes of the measures can be compared across two groups. If it is not measurement invariant, caution should be used when comparing the scores from two groups as they may not be comparable. The research also looked to see if the concept of mindset had discriminant validity when compared with similar concepts. This study also had sections that focused particularly on math attitudes and on middle and high school students as research has shown that those time points tended to be when math interest and achievement in students start to decrease.

The survey consisted of the Dweck Mindset Instrument, a math Mindset Instrument, perceived control scale, math self-concept, math anxiety, math self-efficacy and math interest scales. Two American junior high schools and one American high school were surveyed with 407 students filling out at least part of the survey. One Japanese junior high school and one Japanese high school was surveyed with 426 students filling out at least some of the survey. Dr. Ayumi Tanaka, as well as some of her graduate students, helped immensely with getting in contact with schools to survey. While mindset and math mindset scores correlated positively with positive academic attitudes and negatively with negative academic attitudes, these correlations were not high enough to consider the mindset measures to be measuring the same constructs as the other scales showing that mindset seems to have discriminant validity. Additionally, American students reported more positive academic values, including mindset and math mindset, when compared to Japanese students. While previous research has shown that attitudes like self-concept and self-efficacy tended to be lower in Eastern cultures than Western cultures, having American students have a higher mindset ran counter to the original hypothesis. However, as mentioned these means can only be validly compared if the Mindset measure is measurement invariant.

The mindset measure showed similar correlations with other instruments when comparing the Japanese and American groups of students. Exploratory factor analysis was done on a sample of the students to determine the best fitting model out of a unidimensional model, correlated two-factor model (with incremental and entity questions loading onto the two factors), and two bi-factor models (with the secondary factor being either entity or incremental questions). The two countries showed that their best fitting models, the bi-factor models, were different bi-factor models though the entity bi-factor model still showed a decent fit with the combined sample. It was then no surprise that when the entity bi-factor model was used on the rest of the sample to determine if there was measurement invariance, only configural invariance was met with stricter measurement invariance criteria not being met. This means that while the mindset measure seems to work similarly within these two groups, comparing the means across the two groups may not be appropriate.

This study will be presented at the Association for Psychological Science conference. This research showed that while the mindset measure seems to be measuring a distinct concept and is working similarly within these two countries, it may need additional testing if one wishes to compare these two groups. Studies have shown that positive academic attitudes, including having a more incremental mindset, relates not only to better academic achievement but to academic persistence. With an increasing focus on academic attitudes, particularly with a focus on mathematics, the mindset scale could be useful in adding to this research but may need more psychometrically focused studies on the instrument. Still, this was one of the few academic studies that looked into the measurement invariance of the Dweck Mindset Instrument and more studies should be done on the topic.
